posts._title: Uli Edel – Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (2008)
posts.title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex
posts.excerpt: Germany in the 1970s: Murderous bomb attacks, the threat of terrorism and the fear of the enemy inside are rocking the very foundations of the yet fragile German democracy. posts.title: Straight Time
posts.excerpt: Description: While it rolled in and out of theaters quickly during its brief release in 1978 and hasn’t gained much of a reputation since, Straight Time was one of Dustin Hoffman’s best films of the 1970s, and seen today it still stacks up as one of the finest performances he’s ever given onscreen. posts._title: Forugh Farrokhzad – The House is Black aka Khaneh siah ast (1963)
posts.title: The House is Black
posts.excerpt: From Village Voice: In 1962, beloved and controversial poetess Forugh Farrokhzad went to Azerbaijan and made this short film on the grounds of a leper colony, presaging in 22 minutes the entirety of the Iranian new wave and the international quasi-genre of “poetic nonfiction.” It’s a blackjack of a movie, soberly documenting the village of …

posts.title: Offside
posts.excerpt: Football – or soccer – has been on everyone’s mind this summer because of the spectacular tournament of tournaments, the World Cup. For some, this global extravaganza of athleticism is more than a sporting event; it is a cultural phenomenon. Questions of politics and nationalities are ever-present. posts.excerpt: Quote: One of the less known films from what I feel to be the greatest of Czech directors. In 1947 in the Beskydy mountains are still traces of the war. posts.title: Snack Bar Budapest

posts._title: D.A. Pennebaker – The Complete Monterey Pop festival (1968)
posts.title: The Complete Monterey Pop festival
posts.excerpt: Tom Wiener wrote: Any record of popular culture of the 1960s would be incomplete without at least a mention of Monterey Pop. posts.title: Giliap
posts.excerpt: Quote: Roy Andersson premiered his second feature-length film, “Giliap”, in 1975. The film is a marked departure from “A Swedish Love Story”, and that is no accident.
